dc:description:
The *WASHC5* gene is located on chromosome 8 at 8q24.13 and encodes the WASH complex subunit 5 protein, or strumpellin, a component of the WASH core complex, which activates Arp2/3-mediated actin polymerization and functions in endosome fission. *WASHC5* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Ritscher-Schinzel syndrome 1 in 2013 (Elliott et al., PMID: 24065355). This disorder is characterized by brain malformations, with neurodevelopmental findings, dysmorphic features, and cardiovascular malformations. *WASHC5* has also been associated with autosomal dominant hereditary spastic paraplegia 8 by Valdmanis et al. in 2007 (PMID: 17160902). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found a difference in inheritance pattern and in clinical phenotype between the two disease assertions. Therefore, the diseases were split into Ritscher-Schinzel syndrome 1 (OMIM: 220210) and hereditary spastic paraplegia 8 (OMIM: 603563). The split curation for autosomal recessive hereditary spastic paraplegia 8 has been curated separately.
Evidence supporting the relationship between *WASHC5* and Ritscher-Schinzel syndrome 1 includes case-level data. Elliott et al. (2013, PMID: 24065355) identified a homozygous canonical splice site variant in 10 affected individuals from an isolated First Nations community. A homozygous missense variant was identified in another individual but was not scored (Maddirevula et al., 2020, PMID: 33456446). This gene-disease relationship is not supported by experimental evidence. There are two animal models (one mouse and one zebrafish) reported in the literature but neither provide evidence to support the gene-disease relationship (Bu et al., PMID:32417190) In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on September 17, 2021. It was reevaluated on December 4, 2024 (SOP Version 11). Although a new case report was published (PMID: 36130690), the classification did not change.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Macrocephaly, prominent forehead, low posterior hairline, wide and downslanting palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, coloboma (right iris), low set ears, brachycephaly, CNS findings (increased cisterna magna, unusual frontal horns), ID.

evidence.dc:description: Variant evidence total score is 2.5: 1.5 each for variant 1 and variant 2, then reduced by 0.5 points total for homozygosity.

RT-PCR using RNA from 2 of the affected individuals (no indication which patients were used) and 1 control individual showed a mean 7.85-fold reduction in the relative amount of KIAA0196 transcript in patient samples vs control.  Sanger sequencing of the cloned PCR product from a patient showed that the primary product did not contain exon 27, causing a frameshift and premature stop after amino acid 1128. The variant protein is missing 99 C-terminal amino acids encoded by exons 27-29 and replaced by 68 novel residues. The variant protein is missing 29 consecutive residues that are completely conserved from zebrafish to humans. Western blot analysis indicated that the amount of strumpellin present in the patient was reduced by ~60% compared to control.

evidence.rdfs:label: 09DG00555
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, mild turricephaly, broad hallux, lambdoid suture synostosis (Table S4)

evidence.dc:description: Case not scored, as it's a homozygous Other variant with no functional data.

evidence.rdfs:label: F13-V:1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: F13-V:1 exhibited a recognizable pattern of dysmorphic facial appearance (arched eyebrows, hypertelorism, downslanted palpebral fissures, wide nasal bridge, short philtrum, retromicrognathia, low-set posteriorly rotated small ears with overfolded helices), bilateral humeral fractures, distal metaphyseal irregularity, absent 12th ribs, mildly flattened vertebral bodies and skeletal abnormalities of the hands and feet including absent calcaneal ossification centers, absent fifth middle phalanges and hypoplastic distal phalanges of the fingers (Figure 2H). These peculiar facial and metacarpophalangeal findings raised suspicion of Ritscher-Schinzel syndrome (MIM#220210, MIM#300963, MIM#619135, MIM#619435) when combined with antenatal findings of cerebellar hypoplasia, IUGR, and spontaneous in-utero closure of VSD.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Array-CGH was performed as the first step and yielded normal results in all probands.

evidence.dc:description:
Variant predicted to impact splicing by spliceAI (0.97) but lies outside the canonical splice site. If scored, variant evidence total score is 2.5: 1.5 each for variant 1 and variant 2, then reduced by 0.5 points total for homozygosity. 

Case not scored due to no postnatal phenotype and no functional evidence to prove lof.
Variant is not homozygous; only a single heterozygous variant was identified in this individual; as such, variant was not scored

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Probands were investigated by exome sequencing requested by the treating physician while the segregation studies were performed using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Macrocephaly, plagiocephaly, flat face on profile view, arched eyebrows, downslanted palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, high nasal bridge, broad nasal tip, low set-ears. Bilateral coloboma. Atrial septal defect. Severe DD and ID. Cerebellar hypoplasia, posterior fossa cysts, periventricular leukomalacia.

evidence.dc:description: Four affected siblings, three terminated pregnancies and a 5 years-old female child, carried the compound heterozygous p.Gln78* and p.Arg830Gln variants
Four affected siblings, three terminated pregnancies and a 5 years-old female child, carried the compound heterozygous p.Gln78* and p.Arg830Gln variants
Experiments were to identify susceptibility genes for cardiac abnormalities, not necessarily to support the GDR.
Authors indicate that homozygosity for LoF leads to severe cardiac phenotype and premature death. Some recapitulation of the human cardiac phenotype.
